comment.author: 14673419@N00
comment._content:
Translation:

First World War, Belgium, Air war. A French pilot makes a emergency landing on own terrain after a failed attack on German Zeppelin hangars near Brussels, 1915. The aircraft, a bi-plane, has hit the trees and got stuck. Soldiers climb in the trees

comment.author: 33416765@N03
comment._content: Het vliegtuig is vrijwel zeker een AVRO 504; een type vliegtuig dat werd ingezet ter bestrijding van Zeppelins; zowel in de lucht als aan de grond. Ook hangars waar Zeppelins ondergebracht werden zijn door dit type vliegtuig vaak aangevallen

comment.author: 14279793@N06
comment._content:
"tree-point landing" ... that's funny. But seriously, thank you to whoever posted this photo and thanks for the english translation. I am addicted to WWI aeroplanes and build museum models of them.

I've never seen a WWI plane with roundels (those things that look like targets) on the horizontal stabilizer instead of on the wings. What's up with that? A training plane? (If so, this guy flunked.)
.

comment._content: how is that possible seeing as that aviation hadn't officially begun until the wright brothers accomplished it in the early 1930's????

comment.author: 80144821@N00
comment._content: Actually, according to Wikipedia, the Wright Brothers made their first flight in 1903, and Wilbur Wright actually died in 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers This is not a peer reviewed article, but it explains Belgium's aerial involvement in WW1. www.century-of-flight.net/Aviation%20history/airplane%20a...
